ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The course provided a view of the Enlightenment 'from below' and 'from the margins' by considering (1) less canonical authors and (2) less canonical texts by the 'grands philosophes'. Particular attention was given to the various figures of alterity in 18th-century literature (namely, colonial subjects, feral children, etc.).

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The syllabus was clearly structured and well organized, and the premise of the course-- to interrogate the philosophy of the Enlightenment from its margins-- was theoretically interesting. The course paired primary texts with relevant secondary literature, which was helpful and provided a sense of the field. I would have appreciated more interventions from Professor Saint-Amand, since when he did intervene his readings and comments often opened up new possibility and shed light on the texts in interesting ways.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes-- I think the course offers an important 'counterpoint' to more traditional treatments of Enlightenment thought and culture and reinscribes the histories of colonialism and alterity that remain imminently legible but often ignored in 18th-century literature.
